Emelina F. is 57 years old and resides in Cardona which is located in the Province of Rizal. She lives with her husband and their two adult children. Emelina has a store in her house where she sells basic necessities and all types of products that people use in their homes. She also owns and operates sewing business as her second venture for additional profit making. With that, she has been able to provide other basic needs, allowing them to enjoy life in a simple way.

Over almost 12 years of being an ASHI member, Emelina has shown herself to be working hard to make her dreams come true and hoping that her businesses will continue to be more productive and improve the overall living conditions of her entire family. Knowing that she can access secured financial support through loans has also given her courage and faith that someday, her two children will have a good life and be ready to face their own lives.

Now, Emelina is requesting a loan so that she can have the funds needed to buy more food products and basic household necessities. The remaining funds will be used to support her second venture, her sewing business. This will allow her to attract more customers and increase her sales. She believes this opportunity will give her the confidence to succeed. The financial opportunity of her sari-sari (variety) store and sewing business is one of the best ways to help provide for her family, and she very much wants to lift her family out of poverty. 

Emelina gave her best to develop her two business and hopes if possible, to have a full-fledged mini-grocery store and tailoring shop in the local area someday, so that she can provide employment to others who want to get ahead. The sacrifices that she has encountered are her weapon and inspiration to fight against poverty. 

Her family is grateful to ASHI and Kiva for allowing room for improvements. They love what they do in making their business achievements. The couple’s biggest dreams are providing the best for their family and having a happy family, allowing them an experience full of blessings.

loans.use: To buy more food products and basic household necessities

loans.name: Grace Jemaiyo

texts.en:
Grace Jemaiyo M. is 40 years old and married to Samwel Kerebei, who is a farmer. They have five school-going children between the ages of five and 17. They live in Cheplasgei Eldoret, Kenya. Grace has been operating a general store for the past four years and earns a monthly profit of 10,000 KES.

Grace learned about KADET LTD through marketing awareness done in the area. She is applying for her fourth loan of 60,000 KES from KADET LTD, which she intends to use to buy 16 boxes of cooking oil, eight bags of sugar and 10 crates of soda. With the anticipated profits she plans to buy a posho mill machine.

In the future, her deeper desire is to see her children realizing their goals in life through better education.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil, sugar and soda

loans.name: Jevaan Zaka Allah's Group

texts.en:
Jevaan is a housewife who lives with her husband and four children in Sheikh Ijada, which is a small housing colony in a city named Gujranwala. Gujranwala is famous for its sweetmeat in Pakistan. She is an active lady who prefers to stay at home, fulfills her household responsibilities and takes care of her children.  

Among her four children, three sons are involved in different kinds of work. They left their education after completing the 10th grade and started doing work to financially support their family. Her daughter is only five years old, and has yet not started to attend school.
 
Her husband, Z. A., is involved in the glass business. He makes glass windows, doors and tables by receiving orders from different companies. He has been in this business for over 15 years. In these years, he has successfully obtained a good reputation among his customers due to producing good quality work.   

Jevaan has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy glass in larger quantities, which enables him to fulfill the larger orders on time and to increase his income as well.
 
Jevaan is very confident that her family’s living standard will get improved after the betterment of her husband’s business. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself as a responsible client who paid her installments on time and never missed any meeting.  

Note: In the photo, Jevaan is the lady who holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands.

loans.use: To buy a larger quantity of glass for making windows, doors, etc.

loans.name: Miguela

texts.en:
Miguela C. is from the town of Veruela. She is 61 years old, married, and has five children. Her eldest child is 37 years old, while the youngest is 25. Miguela is a farmer. She plants and harvests rice crops, which she sells to the market. She said it's tedious work but she is happy to be earning from her farm. She said she was able to provide for her family's needs because of her rice farm. Miguela also makes food like rice cakes that she sells around her neighborhood.

Miguela joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Miguela has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Miguela is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Paul Kipkalum

texts.en:
Paul Kipkalum K. is 47 years old and married to Kosgei, who is a housewife. They have three school-going children, aged seven, 10 and 12 years old, respectively. Their residence is in Tuiyo Eldoret, Kenya. He has been in the business of selling milk for 15 years and earns a monthly profit of 25,000 KES.

Paul learnt about KADET LTD through marketing awareness done in the area. He is applying for his first loan of 30,000 KES from KADET LTD, which he intends to use to buy milk for resale. With the anticipated profits he plans to expand his milk business.

In the future, Paul wishes to have rental houses. His deeper desire is to see his children realizing their goals in life through better education.

loans.use: To buy more milk for resale

loans.name: Edwin Kipkorir

texts.en:
Edwin Kipkorir A. is 33 years old and married to Nancy Chepchirchir, who does poultry farming. They have three school-going children aged four, seven and 10. Their residence is in Tuiyo Eldoret, Kenya. Edwin has been in the business of selling milk for eight years and earns a monthly profit of 20,000 KES.

Edwin learned about KADET LTD through marketing awareness done in the area. He is applying for his first loan of 40,000 KES from KADET LTD, which he intends to use to buy more milk for resale. With the anticipated profits he plans to expand his milk business.

In the future, Edwin wishes to have rental houses. His deeper desire is to see his children realizing their goals in life through better education.

loans.use: To buy milk for resale

loans.name: Claudia

texts.en:
Claudia F. is from the village of Canitoan, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 57 years old. Claudia is married and has 8 adult-aged children. To make a living, Claudia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While this is not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling electronic loads (electronic transfer of airtime using text messaging) from several networks like SMART and GLOBE in the local community. Claudia has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Claudia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Claudia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Claudia is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional electronic loads to buy and sell. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Claudia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional electronic loads to buy and sell.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia, 57, works from home as a seamstress to support her family financially. She mainly receives work from neighboring clients. She started this business after her husband’s death a few years ago. Her husband had been the only breadwinner of the family and after his death all responsibilities came onto her shoulders and she worked day and night to improve the financial condition of her family.

Razia is mother to two sons. Her elder son works in a brick furnace manufacturing brick and the younger is the janitor of a private company. They both contribute to the family financially. The family live in Gujranwala, a city located in Punjab and famous in Pakistan for its sweetmeat.
 
Razia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her elder son to start a driving business, as his current work doesn’t give him enough money to cover the family's financial needs. He will use the loan to purchase a rickshaw with which he will provide transportation services to passengers and earn income for the family.

Razia is hopeful that after this loan investment her family’s life will improve and she will be able to marry her elder son very soon. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In the previous loan year, she built good credit behavior and attended every meeting.

loans.use: To buy a rickshaw to start a driving business

loans.name: Kipkemboi

texts.en: Kipkemboi K. has been selling ready-made clothes for the past 14 years. He is 46 years old, married to Josphine Jepkosgei and they have five children, ages 22, 18, 16, 14 and 9 years old. Kipkemboi earns a profit of 9,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) per month from his clothes business. He is applying for his fifth loan of 35,000 KES from KADET after having successfully paid back his other loans. He plans to use this loan to buy more clothes. With the anticipated profits from the expanded business, he plans to buy a plot of land. Kipkemboi hopes to operate a dairy farm and also see his children get enlightened through education and become successful in life.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Albert Kipkoech

texts.en:
Albert Kipkoech S. is 44 years old and married to Mary Jeptanui S.. They are farmers and have seven school-going children, ages 21, 19, 17, 15, 13, 11, and 9 years old. They live in Tuiyo, Eldoret, Kenya. Albert sells milk and has been in this business for 10 years. He earns a monthly profit of 14,000 Kenyan shillings (KES).

Albert learned about KADET through marketing awareness done in the area. He is applying for his first loan of 15,000 KES from KADET which he intends to use to buy milk for resale. With the anticipated profits, he plans to expand his milk  business. In the future, Albert wishes to buy a dairy cow. His deeper desire is to see his children realizing their goals in life through better education.

loans.use: To buy milk to sell

loans.name: Moun

texts.en:
As everyone knows, fish is the main vital fresh food for everybody. In particular, there are families who depend on fishing from Tunle Sap River, which is the best place for fish sheltering. Moun K. is one of those people – she currently depends on selling fish at the busy local market. She sells fish that she either gets from her son or buys from a wholesale supplier. 

Moun K. is married to Mr. Kai, age 52, who works as a soldier at the border of Siem Reap province. Moun K. is a humble mother who has been blessed with six school-aged children. She has requested a loan to purchase more equipment to supply her son's fish-catching business.

loans.use: To purchase more equipment to supply her son's fishing business

loans.name: Melba

texts.en:
Melba C. is from the village of Canitoan, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 49 years old. Melba is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Melba owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, junk foods and instant noodles in the local community. Melba has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Melba joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melba has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Melba is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and working capital. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Melba from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products and working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to complete the necessities for the wedding

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary N. lives in the Nalukolongo neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has five children, none of whom is in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (grandchildren).    

Mary has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 6 days out of every week. Mary sells her products at the market, wholesale and retail.    Mary has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal.     

The main business challenges for Mary include transportation and the rainy season.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van and also to start selling wholesale only.    

Mary lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include medication and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Mumtaz's Group

texts.en:
Mumtaz is a resident of Gujranwala which is located in Punjab and is famous in Pakistan for its sweetmeats. She has lived there in a 3-room brick house with her family in an area called Sheikh Ijada for many years. She is a 53-year-old lady who is married to M. A. and has five sons and one daughter. Her husband operates a grocery store in the nearby market. 
 
Her eldest son does embroidery; the next one is a motor mechanic, and her third son has a furniture-making business. They all contribute their family financially from their earning.  Her remaining 3 children are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education. 

Mumtaz has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s grocery store business. With the loan, he will increase his grocery stock by putting more groceries into it. He started this business 5 years ago and Mumtaz is hopeful that this investment will take her husband’s business to a more profitable position.  

She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application. She hopes that it will be a profitable experience for her and she will be able to marry off her eldest son soon with the help of increased profits from the use of this loan.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery store business

loans.name: Sharon Marie

texts.en:
Sharon Marie M. is from the village of Malinao, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 32 years old. Sharon Marie is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Sharon Marie owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling household products, especially those for cooking, like soy sauce, vinegar, onions, black pepper and garlic, in the local community. Sharon Marie has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Sharon Marie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sharon Marie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Sharon Marie is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products, like spices, to buy and sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Sharon Marie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Paterna

texts.en:
Paterna C. is a 57-year old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: a sari-sari (variety) store and food vending business. She lives in Sitio Tata-an, Barangay Bato, Toledo City, Cebu. 

Paterna has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard at her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 3,000. Paterna is now borrowing PHP 17,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 15,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Paterna aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Prima

texts.en: Prima R. is a married woman who lives in Nangka, DAS Village II, Toledo City, Cebu. She earns a living by operating two business ventures: furniture and pig fattening. Her husband Felix R., who is 38 years old, works as a carpenter to earn a living and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have four children who are between 5 and 13 years old and are currently going to school. Prima joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past nine loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Prima has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 10th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to pay for more logs/lumber. With the expected profits, she will continue to save up for the future and renovate their kitchen. Prima R. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable) woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of materials for the furniture business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en: Maribel B. is from the village of Malinao, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 39 years old. Maribel is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Maribel runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and junk food. She is also buying and selling rice by the kilogram. Maribel has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Maribel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maribel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Maribel is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Maribel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mwanamkuu

texts.en:
Mwanamkuu is a widowed woman with nine children, five girls and four boys. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are clothing, electricity and water bills. 

She operates a Kikoi-selling (cloth used as traditional African clothing) business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Mwanamkuu hopes to renovate her house in the future. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase Kikoi's and building materials to repair her stall. She decided to join Yehu to get loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase Kikoi's and building materials to repair her stall

loans.name: Yator Peter

texts.en:
Yator Peter T. is a businessman, 32 years old;  he operates a retail shop as a primary business and also he manages a mini-bakery and sells the cakes to customers who normally come to his shop. He is married to Rebecca T., and they have four children aged 13 years, 10 years, eight years, and six years respectively. He runs his business in Kapsowar-Eldoret Kenya and has been in this business for about four years.

Yator was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and he has no history with any other MFI .He is applying for a third loan of Kshs 45,000 with KADET LTD which he plans to purchase 20 bales of wheat flour flour for baking, 40 liters of cooking oil and three boxes of baking powder to expand the bakery business and to serve his customers well.

He hopes to expand his business to other towns in the surroundings of Eldoret.

loans.use: To purchase 20 bales of baking flour, 40 litres of cooking oil, and three  boxes of baking powder

loans.name: Richelle

texts.en:
Richelle R. is 30 years old, married and supports her family by operating two businesses: selling frozen food and running a general store. She lives in Barangay Tutay, a part of the municipality of Pinamungajan within Cebu province. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her frozen food business and general store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 4,000 PHP.

Richelle is now borrowing 12,000 PHP to use for additional working capital. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 9,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Richelle aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They are on a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: For additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith E., from the town of Veruela, is 34 years old, married and has four children aged 17, 13, 11 and 9. Judith and her husband are both farmers, cultivating their land for rice crops. Judith is hoping their harvest will increase, and she also finds ways to earn extra money by cooking food that she sells in their neighborhood.

Judith joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from CEVI, she is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Annabell

texts.en:
Annabell B. is married to Leonardo B. Jr., who is 44 years old, works as a fisherman and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have two children who are fifteen and fourteen years old. They live in Polacion 1 of Tinago Barangay, a part of Dumaguete City in Negros Oriental province of the Western Visayas islands. Annabell runs a general store and has a food vending business.

Annabell joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Annabell has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 8,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 5,000 PHP, lifting the family's standard of living.

This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing 10,000 PHP, which she intends to use to buy stock for her general store and food to sell so that she can continue to save for the education of her children. Annabell B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They are on a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To buy stock for her general store and more food to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose A., 24-year-old widowed mother of three children aged 10, 8, and 5 years, is a businesswoman who has been selling fruits and vegetables for the last two years. Rose learned about KADET LTD from market awareness done by KADET staff in Narok town, and this will be her second loan with which she will buy more fruits and vegetables to increase her stock. With the anticipated profit from this loan, she hopes to rent a permanent building to operate her business from.

Despite her being a widow, Rose is hardworking and determined to achieve her set goal.

loans.use: To spend Ksh 20,000 to buy more bananas, spinach and a variety of fruits

loans.name: Analou

texts.en:
Analou L. is 29 years old, married and has three school-aged children. She is from the village of Kilikili within the municipality of Wao, Lanao del Sur province of the Northern Mindanao islands. Analou runs a sari-sari (variety) shop from which she buys and sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and instant noodles to the local community. Analou has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Analou joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Analou is requesting a new loan, her third from HSPFI, of 5000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products for her shop. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita C. is a married woman who lives in Purok Tuhay, Brgy. Canmoros, Binalbagan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: a General Store and a Rice Retailer business. Her husband Francisco, who is 66 years old, works as a Driver to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. 

They have 3 children who are between 33 to 38 years old. Teresita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1992 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Teresita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 3,500, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to use to buy stocks for the general store and rice to sell so that she could continue to save up for future improvement of business.   Teresita C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF)  is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stocks to sell

loans.name: Parsalunye Ole

texts.en:
Parsalunye Ole M., 32 years old and married to Purity M., supports three people in his family. Parsalunye has been a wheat farmer for the last four years in a productive area of the country.

He learned about KADET lTD through a marketing campaign conducted by KADET staff in his area of residence. This will be his second loan with which he will buy pesticides to spray his growing wheat to prevent it from being invaded by pests. He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more farmland to meet the demand for wheat.

A hardworking man determined to achieve his set goals, Parsalunye's hope and dream is to become a large scale farmer and have his own farm machinery.

loans.use: To buy pestcide to prevent his wheat from being invaded by pests.

loans.name: Almaas' Group

texts.en:
Almaas lives in Gujranwala which is located in Punjab and famous for its sweetmeat in Pakistan. She has lived there in a 2-room brick house with her family for many years. She is a housewife as well as a working woman. She operates a small canteen in a nearby school, where she sells fast food like sandwiches, French fries, burgers and cold drinks to school children and teachers.

Her husband is a government employee and earns a meager income. She is the mother of 2 daughters and a son. Her son drives a rickshaw and her eldest daughter is a school teacher. Her youngest daughter is 6 years old and studying in kindergarten.

Almaas has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her canteen business. She will use the loan in purchasing required items such as potatoes, cooking oil, bread, spices and cold drinks in bulk quantity that enable her to make fast food to sell through the canteen. She has been doing this business for over 10 years and she is sure that this investment will prove profitable for her and she will easily repay the loan. She is a new borrower with Asasah and hopes that it will be a long term relationship for her.

Note: In the photo, the lady who holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands is Almaas.

loans.use: To buy required items for canteen business

loans.name: Alona

texts.en:
Alona Q. is from the town of Veruela. She is 45 years old. Alona is single. To make a living, Alona owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Alona is happy that she is able to help her family financially.

Alona joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alona has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Alona is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Illuminada

texts.en:
Illuminada J. is a widow who lives in Purok Tuhay, Brgy. Canmoros, Binalbagan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a business venture: a General Store business. 

Illuminada joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1992 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Illuminada has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000, which she intends to use to buy raw materials for her home repairs and stocks for the general store so that she could continue to save up for future improvement of business.  Illuminada J. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stocks to sell

loans.name: Anhbayar

texts.en: Anhbayar O. is a 22 year old single man who lives with his parents and siblings in Hovd province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent. His mother works as a cook. Two of his siblings attend university while his other two siblings attend local school. Anhbayar operates a raw material retail business in his town. He began his business in 2005 with the help of his brother and after hard work and determination, has built a stable operation. He is planning to purchase many goats at wholesale price in order to sell in the upcoming winter when prices for cashmere from goats might rise. Anhbayar is a business-minded and well-balanced man. He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more goats to sell for profit.

loans.use: To purchase goats

loans.name: Ulziijargal

texts.en:
Ulziijargal is 41 years old and lives with her husband and 3 children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a wooden house. Her 20-year-old daughter Bolorchimeg attends a university. Her younger 2 children are attending a local secondary school. 

She has been operating a retail business and vegetable trade business since 2006 with her husband. She has purchased a car and started building a new wooden house right next to her place by her earnings.   After years of successful operation she has gained great business experience and has a loyal customer base. 

Ulziijargal is very hardworking and hopes to continue her success in the future and says, I would like to provide my children with a good education and good morals. She is requesting a loan to purchase a heating system in her new house.

loans.use: Purchase heating system for her new house.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine E. is from the village of Kinura, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 34 years old.  Josephine is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a business venture in the food sector running a bakeshop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from baking & selling a variety of bread like monay bread and loaf bread for the local community.  Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital.  Josephine is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional cooking ingredients and working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 


About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines.  It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baking ingredients and working capital

loans.name: Jusilyn

texts.en:
Jusilyn S. is from the town of Veruela. She is 35 years old, married and has five children. Her eldest is 18 years old. To make a living, Jusilyn owns and operates a business growing crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. Jusilyn also sells ready-to-wear and used clothes.

Jusilyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jusilyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Gilma

texts.en:
Gilma G. is from the village of Kinura, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 30 years old. Gilma is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Gilma owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle or habal-habal services with her husband as the driver to local community members. Gilma has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Gilma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to provide service. Gilma is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the motorcycle. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Gilma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 


About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tools needed to maintain motorcycle for business.

loans.name: Bandihuu

texts.en: Bandihuu C. is 58 years old and lives with her husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her husband live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in one of the ger districts on the outskirts of the large city. Her eldest son currently works and lives in Korea. Her husband is retired and operates a taxi service using his own car. Bandihuu also owns and operates a micro bus transportation service and takes passengers from one side of Ulaanbaatar to the other. She has been engaged this business since 2005 and has gained much experience. Bandihuu is a gentle and polite person. She is requesting an 800,000 MNT loan in order to purchase repair parts for her vehicles, as well as for her household consumption.

loans.use: To purchase repair parts

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora B. is from the village of Francfort, Bumbaran, Lanao del Sur. She is 41 years old. Leonora is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Leonora owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and instant noodles in the local community. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Leonora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Leonora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is a widowed woman with one child who attends school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, electricity, the water bill and school fees for the family.

For over eight years, she has operated a restaurant and fresh water sale business from home. Her potential customers are neighbours and passersby. Mwanaisha faces the challenge of competition from other restaurant operators. She hopes to open her own hotel in the future. 

Mwanaisha decided to join Yehu to access loans. With the 15,000 KES she wants to purchase wheat flour, baking flour and cooking oil for her restaurant.

loans.use: To purchase flour and cooking oil for her restaurant

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine M. is from the village of Francfort, Bumbaran, Lanao del Sur. She is 33 years old. Josephine is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, coffee in sachets and chocolate drinks in sachets in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and build working capital. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rasoolan Ghulam Ali's Group

texts.en:
Rasoolan lives in Gujranwala, which is located in Punjab and famous for its sweetmeats in Pakistan. She has been living there in a three-room brick house with her family for over 26 years. She is a talented lady and operates a sewing business at her home to supplement the income of her family. She collects orders from her neighborhood clients and completes the orders on time to earn an income. She is married to G. A., who is a private entrepreneur and operates a cigarette selling business. He operates his shop from the center of the market and handles a good clientele base. He keeps every brand of cigarette in his shop to fulfill the needs of his customers on time.  

Rasoolan has two sons. Both of them have been involved in the business of selling glass for over seven years. They sell glass to different glass companies on orders and contribute to their family financially from their earnings. Rasoolan has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. He will invest the loan in purchasing more cigarettes brands for his cigarette shop. Rasoolan is hopeful that through this loan investment her husband’s income will increase and his clientele base will improve as well. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah. This is her second loan application. In the previous loan year, she built good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy cigarette brands in bulk quantity for selling

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda V. is from the village of Francfort, Bumbaran, Lanao del Sur. She is 34 years old. Florenda is married and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, Florenda owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Florenda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Florenda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florenda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase land to raise additional livestock. Florenda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Florenda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria G. lives in the Naguru neighborhood of the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has four children, all of whom are in school. Victoria has a business selling second-hand clothes. She has been in this business for six years, and works six days a week. Victoria sells her products at the market, by means of wholesale/retail. Victoria has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of second-hand clothes.     

She also generates additional income through tailoring. The main business challenge(s) for Victoria include transportation and the rainy season. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and also to educate her children up to university. Victoria lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity, but not to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Estrellita

texts.en:
Estrellita S., photographed at her home, is from the town of Veruela. She is married and has six children. Her eldest child is 20 years old while the youngest is only 3. To make a living, Estrellita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Estrellita works hard to sustain her children's education because she wants them to finish college.

Estrellita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrellita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Estrellita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Argen

texts.en:
Argen B. is from the village of Malinao, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 21 years old. Argen is married and has two young infants. To make a living, Argen owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, junk foods and beverages in the local community. Argen has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Argen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Argen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Argen is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Argen from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Phon

texts.en:
Phon S., 24 years old, is a car taxi driver in Kompong Cham Province where he lives with his elderly mother, a local farmer. He runs his business along the streets from his province to Phnom Penh City every day. Most of his family’s income comes from his car taxi driving, and he typically earns an average of US$ 10 a day. 

Unfortunately, his car has broken down during use, and now his savings are not enough to buy car parts. To solve the problem, Phon S. has decided to seek a loan of US$ 1100 from Kiva, which he will use to purchase car parts to repair his broken-down car.

loans.use: To purchase car equipment to repair his broken-down taxi

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose N. lives in the Ndeeba neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has two children, both of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (a sister and a brother).   

 Rose has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 8 years, and she works 6 days out of every week.  Rose sells her products at the market, both wholesale and retail.    Rose has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal.     She also generates additional income through part-time teaching.

 The main business challenges for Rose include transportation and the rainy season.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and also to educate her children up to university.   Rose lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include paying utility bills, feeding the family, rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine B. lives in the Naguru neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has two children, both in school.  Catherine has a business  selling fruits and vegetables.  She has been in this business for three years, and she works six days out of every week.  Catherine sells her products at the market, both wholesale and retail.    

Catherine has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of tomatoes, onions and oranges, pineapples.     She also generates additional income through selling piped water. The main business challenges for Catherine include transportation and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start going to farmers directly and also to educate her children up to university.   

 Catherine lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and  piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include paying utility bills, feeding the family and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more  boxes of tomatoes, onions, oranges and pineapples

loans.name: Millicent Akinyi

texts.en:
Millicent Akinyi W. is 31 years old, married to Samson W., and a mother of four school-going children.

Millicent is a business lady and she  sells  baskets, charcoal 'jikos' (little stoves) and other home products. She has been in this business for the last three years and it has been doing well as local residents are her frequent customers.

She learned about KADET LTD  from a market awareness outreach done by KADET staff in Bomet town. This will be her first loan which she is planning to spend on buying more stock of 'jikos' and baskets as she  believes that she is approaching high season [CHRISTMAS].

Her dream is that she will own a big hardware shop and be a wholesaler supplying her goods to different towns.

She is a hard-working lady and determined to achieve her set goal.

loans.use: to spend Ksh 40,000 to increase her stock.

loans.name: Parkimaso Ole

texts.en: Parkimaso Ole N. is 45 years old. He is a farmer and supports eight people in his family. His spouse is Naponu N. and they have children aged between six and 18 years. Naponu is a housewife and also helps Parkimaso in his farming. Parkimaso has been a wheat farmer for the last twelve years. This will be his second loan which he is planning to spend on chemicals and fertilizer. He is planning to use the anticipated profit from his loan to expand his farm by renting more land to increase his wheat production. His dream is that he will become a large-scale farmer and be financially stable to better support his family.

loans.use: to buy chemical and fertilizer for his wheat farm.

loans.name: Diostita

texts.en:
Diostita is a hard-working mother who offers tricycle transportation to earn a living. (Her tricycle is a motorcycle with sidecar.) This is much more expensive than a tri-bike but the owners make a bigger income. Her supportive husband, Reynaldo, is a driver and manages their transport business. Diostita and Reynaldo offer good service to people in their village. She appreciates that the organization has helped her improve her business and her quality of life.

Diostita has requested a loan of 15,000 Php for the maintenance of their tricycle including needed spare parts. She hopes to buy another tricycle in the future for more work. Diostita is hoping that her transport business will help her with the financial needs of her family and support her grand childrens' education so that they are able to move forward out of poverty. She positively believes their lives can be changed.

loans.use: to buy needed spare parts for her tricycle

loans.name: James Kilesi

texts.en:
James Kilesi N. is 26-years-old. He is married to Lydia and is a father of two school-going children. He has been a farmer on his own piece of land for the last six years.
	
He learned about KADET LTD through a friend who is a KADET registered client. This will be his second loan which he is planning to spend on fertilizer and chemicals for his ten-acre wheat farm. He hopes to buy some farm machinery with the anticipated profit. He is a hard-working man determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and chemicals for his ten acre wheat farm

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace N. lives in the Busega neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of her sister's children. Grace has a business selling second-hand clothes. She has been in this business for over 10 years and  works 6 days a week selling her clothing at the market. 

Grace has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. She also generates additional income through making hand crafts. Her main business challenges include transportation and thieves. Her goal for her business is to start selling wholesale and to educate her children up to university level. Grace lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Tobiko

texts.en:
Tobiko O. is 36 years old. He is a farmer and supports five people in his family. His spouse is Nanyikae and they have children aged between one and 15 years. Nanyikae is a housewife and also helps Tobiko in his farming. Tobiko has been a wheat farmer for the last ten years. This will be his second loan and he is planning to buy chemical and fertilizer. Wheat can be affected by pests that destroy it if not sprayed.

He is planning to use the anticipated profit to rent a bigger piece of land to increase his wheat production. His dream is to become a large-scale farmer and be financially stable enough to support his family.

loans.use: to buy chemicals and fertilizer for his wheat farm.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia S. is from the town of Veruela. She is 46 years old. Delia is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Delia owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Delia's husband, who is also a farmer, has a part-time job in a welding shop. Delia said she and her husband do their best to provide for their family's needs.

Delia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Delia has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Delia is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Reuben Kipngetich

texts.en:
Reuben Kipngetich K. is 32 years old.  His spouse is Jackline and they have three children aged seven years, five years and three years old. Reuben operates a motorbike business in Bomet town and he has been in this business for one year.

He learned about KADET LTD  from a market awareness outreach done by Kadet staff in Bomet town. This will be his first loan which he is planning to spend on buying some spare parts and servicing his motorbike.

From the anticipated profit from the business he plans to buy another motorbike and employ a rider. Reuben's dream is that he will own a fleet of cars, and also be a large-scale poultry farmer.

He is a hard-working gentle man with great vision.

loans.use: buy spare parts and service his motorcycle

loans.name: Dative

texts.en:
Dative is 28 years old and single. She lives with her parents and she has to contribute in her family as far as household expenses are concerned. Dative is a businesswoman and she owns a business selling various products such as: cooking oil, tomatoes, breads, juice, and so on. This is her first year of successful operation in her business. Dative employs two people from her community and the hours of her grocery are from 6 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day.

Dative is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through purchasing more foodstuffs for sale. With this loan, Dative will be more effective and more efficient.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Bushra's Group

texts.en:
Bushra lives in Gujranwala which is famous in Pakistan for its sweetmeats. Gujranwala is a big city with a high cost of living. So it is very difficult for Bushra and her husband to afford the living expenses for themselves and their six daughters. That’s why they couldn’t educate their daughters and they have remained illiterate. 

Bushra operates a clothes-sewing  business at her home. She mainly works for her neighborhood clients in order to supplement the income of her family. Her husband is a rickshaw driver and he also has a business selling fruit. They work very hard to put three meals a day on the table for the family. They all live in a 2-room brick house in the area called Naseem colony where they moved 10 years ago. 
 
Bushra has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s fruit-selling business. He will invest the loan in purchasing seasonal fruit from the fruit markets in bulk. The bulk purchasing will allow him to meet the demand of his customers and increase his sales. Bushra is very confident that her husband’s seven years of experience will give him the right direction and the loan investment will help him for financial growth. 
 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself a responsible client who paid her installments on time and never missed any meeting.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruit in bulk

loans.name: Elarian

texts.en:
Elarian S. is a 41-year-old from Centro Norte, Culasi Antique, Philippines married to Emelio S.. The fruit of their sweetest love are their four children. Her eldest child is already 14 years old while the youngest is 6 years old and all of them are still studying. Ice cream vending is their primary source of  income; this is where they get money for their daily expenses. 

Since all of their children are studying, they must strive hard in order to survive and meet the basic needs of the family. They wake up early in the morning just to prepare the ice cream because after their breakfast her husband sells that ice cream in the nearby neighborhoods. As food vendors, they maintain the quality of their products so that they gain more customers because they say, customers are very important in business.

Aside from ice cream vending, Elarian also makes salted and coated peanuts and she sells them to their neighbors and distributes to some stores. 

Elarian has been an active member of ASHI Antique North Branch since 2005. She maintains 100%  rate in repayment, attendance and project. She has also accessed incentive loans of ASHI such as House Repair Loan and Educational Loan because of her good performance as a member.

Her biggest dream is to improve their production and to send their children to school until college. She wants their children to become professionals someday. They also wish that someday their business will improve so that they can help their relatives and neighbors by providing jobs for them.

For her next loan in ASHI, Elarian is planning to buy a tricycle (three-wheeled transport vehicle), so that their products will reach to other neighborhoods and municipalities especially since the fiesta in some neighborhoods in Culasi is approaching. 

During fiesta and summer days, ice cream sells quickly; that is why they want to take this opportunity. She needs Php 30,000 in order to realize these dreams and if this request is granted, it would be a great help to them in providing for the basic needs of the family.

loans.use: buying a "tricycle" to transport their ice cream

loans.name: Jackline Chelangat

texts.en:
Jackline Chelangat M. is 32-years-old. She is a married and a mother of four children between the ages of three and 15. She is a business lady who sells cloths and shoes on a busy street in Silibwet town on the outskirts of Narok. She has been running this business for the last two years.

She learned about KADET LTD from other women who are already registered as clients. This will be her first loan. She is planning to increase her stock by buying more clothes, as there will be great demand because of the upcoming Christmas season. With the profits she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, she plans to rent a permanent shop where she can sell her clothes and shoes. She plans to open another shop and create employment for other people. 

Her future dream is that she will be able to build her own house and run the shop from her own premises. Jackline believes she is hard working, and she only needs the resources to attain her goals.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Lhagvasuren

texts.en: Lhagvasuren D. is 41 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Harhorin, the ancient capital city of the Mongolian empire. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His eldest son is a university student, and his daughter attends a college while his youngest son attends a local elementary school. His wife works in the food factory. Lhagvasuren used to work in the food factory from 1992 to 1995. Since 1992, he has also been herding people's livestock. Lhagvasuren is a modest, honest man and says, " I hope to provide a good education for my three children." He is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan to pay for his eldest son's tuition fee.

loans.use: To pay his oldest son's tuition fee

loans.name: Paul Kipkirui

texts.en:
Paul Kipkirui T. is 44 years old, and he supports a family of four. His spouse Joyce T. is a business woman who contributes Kshs 3,000 per month to the family’s total income. Paul is a businessman who sells second hand clothes on a busy street in Silibwet town on the outskirts of Narok town. He mostly deals with menswear, especially jackets and T-shirts though you will sometimes find some ladies clothes. He has been in this business for the last 18 years and he makes good profit. 

Paul learnt about KADET LTD through a friend who is already a registered member in KADET. This will be his first loan which he is planning to use to buy more stock of second hand clothes, especially men’s trousers.

He hopes to use the anticipated profit from this loan to expand his business and open up another clothing shop. Paul's dream is to become a wholesale seller, and open up a boutique shop where he can be dealing in clothes for both men and women.

He is a hardworking man with a great vision.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to increase his stock

loans.name: Narantsetseg

texts.en: Narantsetseg is 42 years old.  She is a single mother, living with her son in Ulaanbaatar, capital of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic tent.  Her son Gantulga is 28 years old.  He works as a plumber for a construction company.  He works only in the summertime.  She operates a meat trading business at Kharkorin, the most crowded market in Ulaanbaatar. She has been operating this business since 1998 and has expanded her business with a loyal customer base.  She says: "it has been very difficult these past years and now my business is getting better."  Battsetseg is requesting a loan to purchase construction materials for her old house. This is her only income.  She is a very intelligent and patient person.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for her old house.

loans.name: Jean Bosco

texts.en:
Jean Bosco is 26 years old and married with two children; the first one is 4 years old and the younger one is 2 years old. Jean Bosco is a businessman and his wife does not work, so that's why Jean Bosco has to work hard in order to provide all that is necessary for his family. Jean Bosco has an experience of five years and he employs one person as a helper. The hours of his daily activities are from 6 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day.

Jean Bosco is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding his business through purchasing more products such as cosmetics products, powdered milk, cooking oil, and so on.

loans.use: Purchasing additional products for his store

loans.name: Farzana Abdul Wahid's Group

texts.en:
Farzana is a resident of Gujranwala which is famous for its sweetmeats in Pakistan. She has been living there with her family for over 15 years in a two-room brick house. She is 40 years old and married to 47-year-old A. W., who has a business selling construction supplies. She is a mother of three sons and three daughters. Her eldest son completed his degree and works as a compounder at a medical clinic. Her other children are enrolled in school and getting their education.  

It is very difficult for one person to bear all the household and educational expenses at this time, when the cost of living has become very high. That’s why Farzana supports her husband financially through her rice-selling business. She buys rice from the city Sialkot for cheap rates and earns a good profit by selling them at the market.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, her husband will buy construction supplies, such as cement, sand and bricks, in bulk quantity, which will enable him to fulfill the larger orders on time and to increase his profit. Farzana is hopeful that this loan investment will become very beneficial for her husband’s business and increase his monthly income.

Note: In the photo, Farzana is the one who holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) in her hands.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies in bulk quantity

loans.name: Narmandah

texts.en: Narmandah L. is 44 years old and a single mother who lives with two adult children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her children live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her youngest daughter attends university, while she operates a construction material trade business in a stall at Narantuul, the largest and main market in the city. She has been engaged in this business since 1990, right after the opening of Narantuull market, and has since gained many years of experience. She is planning to expand her business and have her own shop where she can sell her products in the future. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan in order to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To buy more materials

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mrs. Mao P. is a single mother caring for four children in Battambang Province. All four of the children attend the local school and are dependent on her income. She married years ago, but divorced her husband. 

Mrs. Mao P. is a local farmer. She owns a piece of land that she inherited from her grandmother. She grows different kinds of crops on her land, such as cabbages, cucumbers, and morning glories, which she sells to buyers every two or three months when the plants mature. 

Mrs. Mao P. is a sacrificing and determined woman who tries to earn money to ensure her children will attain the highest level of education. She faces a difficult season if she is not able to irrigate her crops. She is taking out her loan to purchase some pipe to connect with her existing machine to pump water for her crops. The rest of the funds will be used to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase some pipes to connect with her existing machine to pump water for her crops

loans.name: Lidiya

texts.en:
Lidiya is a market entrepreneur from Pershotravensk, Pavlograd region. She sells dressy women’s clothing items, evening gowns and fur coats in one of the local markets called ‘Yuzhnyi’ (‘Southern’).
