Women who shop at the market know Lidiya’s kiosk for its nice quality clothes and her good taste. Lidiya is always willing to help her customers choose the best outfit for special occasions. She has been in the market for 10 years.  

Lidiya is requesting a loan of 15,000 Grivnyas to purchase seasonal merchandise for her kiosk and thus meet customer demand. Lidiya loves her job and is hoping to grow both professionally and economically in the future.

loans.use: to purchase seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Oyuntungalag

texts.en:
Oyuntungalag G. is 48 years old and lives with her daughter in their own apartment in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. She has two children; her daughter attends university while her son lives on his own by working as a private businessman. 

Oyuntungalag operates a consumer goods sales business at a stand at the local market in Bayanzurh district. She has been engaged this business since 2005 and has built up a stable operation. Over the years of operation, she has gained much experience as a retail trader. She hopes to continue to grow her business in the future. She needs more funds to increase her working capital therefore she is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to expand her product line.

loans.use: To buy more products

loans.name: Katerina

texts.en:
Katerina is divorced with two grown daughters. She is an entrepreneur from Beregovo, Western Ukraine. Katerina sells groceries in the food department of a local mall. She has been working in this sphere of trade for 8 years. Katerina has gained good knowledge in marketing and sales. She always offers fresh merchandise at affordable prices and has many loyal customers. Currently, Katerina has 15,000 Grivnyas in inventory. Her monthly net profit amounts to 3,000 Grivnyas.  

Katerina is seeking a 10,000 Grivnya loan to increase her working capital and purchase additional food items for her kiosk. She is very customer-friendly. This timely financial support will be crucial for her as her small venture is the only source of income for her and her daughters.

loans.use: to increase her turnover capital

loans.name: Laurencia

texts.en:
Laurencia S. is from the town of Veruela. She is 65 years old. Laurencia is married and has eight grown-up children. She has been farming for quite a long time now. She plants and harvests rice crops, which she sells to the market. Laurencia still wants to be able to provide for her family and also her grandchildren. She hopes for her family to be healthy and happy always. 

Laurencia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Laurencia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to buy seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Vilma's Group

texts.en: Vilma C. runs a general store selling both food and daily use products in her community. She is 41 years old, married and has two school-aged children. They are from the village of Buena Suerte, Cauayan City, Isabela. Vilma has been in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2007, Vilma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Vilma is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her fourth loan from ASKI. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. Vilma is the leader of a five member group accessing a loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. She hopes that ASKI will grant their loan as soon as possible to cover their daily expenditures and for the expansion and improvement of their businesses. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is divorced with an 8-year-old son, Norbert. She is a clothing sales entrepreneur from Beregovo, Western Ukraine. Eva sells men’s and women’s clothing in her little store at the local mall called ‘Image’. She launched this venture five years ago. Presently, she has already invested 40,000 grivnyas in the trade. Her monthly net profit amounts to 4,000 grivnyas.  

Eva is requesting a loan of 10,000 grivnyas to purchase seasonal clothing in bulk for retail sale in her store. She usually buys inventory from wholesalers in Hungary; therefore, her merchandise is good quality and comes at a balanced price. Eva is very energetic and hardworking. She always tries to keep her business standards high which has helped her keep loyal clientele.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Lidiya

texts.en:
Lidiya is an entrepreneur from Pavlograd. She sells terry cloth robes and women’s lingerie in the central marketplace of her hometown. She has been in this business for 10 years. Lidiya’s husband is actively helping her with the sales. 

Lidiya is seeking a loan of 10,000 grivnyas to purchase additional merchandise for retail sale in her vending pavilion. She has the rich experience and practical skills to present her merchandise in a way that will attract more clients. Lidiya is planning to invest the profit in further expansion of her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Anthony Kiprotich

texts.en:
Anthony Kiprotich K. is 33 years old. He is married and the father of one child, age six years old. He is a businessman who sells clothes and cushions on a busy street in Silibwet, a town on the outskirts of Narok town. He has been running this business for the past year.

Anthony learned about KADET from friends who are already registered as clients. This will be his first loan. He is planning to increase his stock by buying more clothes and cushions to sell. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to rent a permanent shop for his clothing sales and he plans to open another shop to create employment for other people. In the future, Antony wants to own a house and run his shop on his own premises. Anthony says he is hardworking and only needs the resources to attain his goals.

loans.use: To increase his stock

loans.name: Angelita's Group

texts.en: Angelita M.'s main source of income comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. She is 54 years old, married and has four grown-up children. She is from the village of Disimuray, Cauayan City, Isabela. Angelita has been in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Angelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase breeding livestock. Angelita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock to raise and sell. This will be her third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. Angelita is the leader of an eight member group accessing a loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock to raise and sell in future

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric is 37 years old and married with two children who are 9 years old and five years old. This family also takes care of one child who is a relative. Eric drives a taxi car and his wife does not work. This is his fifth successful year in his business operation and the hours of his business are from 6 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day.

Eric is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to buy equipment for his car. With this loan, Eric will be able to attract more passengers and he will be able to earn more profits.

loans.use: To purchase some equipment for his car

loans.name: Lono

texts.en: Lono D. is currently in the business of selling clothes, shoes, and other items in a shop. She is requesting a loan to stock more clothes to sell.  Lono is 30 years old and is married to a businessman. She has two children and both of them go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To stock more clothes to sell

loans.name: Nigora

texts.en: R. Nigora is 29 years old. She is divorced and has no children. Nigora has a tailoring business at a tailoring shop. Her business is sewing national women's dresses. Her workmanship is very good and, being young, she has a good eye for design. She is very organized and has a good head for business. She has had this business for 12 years and this is her second loan from IMON International. With her loan, Nigora will buy more material for sewing dresses. Nigora smiles when asked what her dreams are for the future. She quickly replies that she plans to open a workshop, hire seamstresses and expand her business. With her spirit, she will surely succeed. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of materials for sewing women's dresses.

loans.name: Song's Group

texts.en:
The four people pictured in the photograph are low-income people who are jointly requesting a loan. They are all living in Siem Reap Province. One of these people, Mrs. Song S., age 27, has been selected by the other group members to be the leader. Song S. currently owns a small shop. She sells some plates to the wholesaler and also sells in the market. She typically makes around $3 of profit each day to ensure that her family has a comfortable life. She has been married for many years to Savuth, 33, a ferryboat operator, and they have two children. Mrs. Song S. wants to add more capital to expand her business, but her account does not contain enough money to make it possible. That is why Mrs. Song S. would like to request a loan to purchase more plates to sell.   

There are three other members in this group who have requested loans. They are using the loans for the following activities:
Mrs. K. is applying for a loan to buy grocery items to sell.
Mrs. C. is asking for a loan to repair her broken motorbike.
Mrs. S. is applying for a loan to repair her broken boat.

loans.use: To purchase more plates to sell

loans.name: Nyume

texts.en:
Nyume P. is currently in the business of selling local brew and beer at her bar and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. 

Nyume is 33 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has three children and two of her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Nazira

texts.en: Nazira is married with 5 children. She sells kid’s clothing in the central marketplace. She has been working with this type of inventory for 11 years. Nazira is requesting a loan of $1,200 US to increase her stock. She is hoping to broaden her seasonal merchandise and boost her autumn sales as a result. Nazira has always had a serious and responsible business approach. It has helped her build a sustainable venture bringing her stable income. She is hoping to continue expanding her trade in the future. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase new goods for selling in order to increase her range of goods.

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita J. is a 73-year-old woman from Centro Poblacion, Culasi, Antique, Philippines.  She is married to Jesus J. who is 72 years old.  All of their children have their own families and their own houses.

Although she is 73 years old, she is still strong enough to run her business and is mature in dealing with problems.

Estelita and Jesus are both industrious and work hand in hand in order to survive without depending on their children.  Actually, they are the ones who help their children and grandchildren.

The buying and selling of salt is their primary source of income, but sometimes during the fishing season she also engages in fish vending. 

Her loan from ASHI is a big help for them because through the capital entrusted to them, they earn an income and through their income they are able to afford their needs and wants. They already have their own business stalls in the market. Moreover, these businesses not only give them an income, but they also provide pleasure to her.  

She is applying for a 10,000.00 PHP loan. This amount will be utilized as additional capital to help her buy and sell more salt. She hopes that someday she can become a wholesaler of salt for the entire municipality.

loans.use: To buy more salt to sell

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John L. is currently in the business of selling various items at her shop like cartons of salt and bags of sugar, and is requesting a loan to stock more sugar, salt, and maize flour to sell.  

John is 30 years old and is married to a husband who holds a job in the government. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

loans.use: To stock more sugar, salt, and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Costant Mulwale Pascal

texts.en:
Costant Mulwale Pascal A. is 60 years old.  He is married to Lucia Mulwale, who is a farmer, and provides a source of additional income for the family. They have four adult children ages 44, 40, 38, and 36 years old. They live in Kibomet Kitale-Kenya.  He operates a butcher shop and has been in this business for 10 years, earning a monthly profit of 20,000 KES.

Costant learned about KADET LTD through a credit officer and is applying for a loan of 80,000 KES, with which he intends to buy four cows. With the anticipated profits, he plans to expand his butchery business.

In the future, Costant wishes to operates a supermarket and create job opportunities. His deeper desire is to live a standard type of life.

loans.use: To buy four cows

loans.name: Kaku

texts.en:
Kaku E. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs like maize flour and green vegetables. She is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and greens like okra for sale.  

Kaku is 48 years old and is widowed.  She has one child who does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

loans.use: To stock tomatoes and greens for sale

loans.name: Umarhon

texts.ru: Каримов Умархон проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 50 лет. Женат, имеет 3 детей. Образование среднее. Более 5 лет занимается торговлей. У него магазин со смешенным ассортиментом. В этом бизнесе ему помогает жена. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота. Он хочет расширить свою деятельность.
texts.en: Umarhon K. lives in the Vahdat district.  He is 50 years old, married and has 3 children.  He has a secondary education.  Umarhon has been involved in retail sales for over 5 years.  He has a store with various merchandise.  His wife helps him with this business.  Umarhon is requesting this loan in order to increase goods turnover.  He wants to expand his business.

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Henry Wekesa

texts.en:
Henry Wekesa M., 42, is a hardworking man, married to Rose Mutiembu. Together they have six children who are 12 years old (twins), 9 years, 8 years, and 5 years (twins). He has been operating a poultry farm for the past four years, and he earns a monthly income of Kshs.31,000.

When he learned about KADET LTD (and it happens that he has no history with any other MFI), he immediately applied for the loan of Kshs. 80,000 from KADET LTD, which he intends to use to buy stock of poultry feed and more poultry to keep so that he may have more eggs to sell to his customers. He plans to use the profits from the expanded business to start dairy farming, which is also very marketable in Kitale.

Henry hopes to grow his business and become the leading local investor, and to see his children realizing their dreams in life through education.

loans.use: To buy stock of poultry feed and more poultry to increase egg sales

loans.name: Nafisha

texts.en: Nafisha G. is currently in the business of selling beans, bread and tomatoes at Gabat market and is requesting a loan to stock more bread and tomatoes to sell.  Nafisha is 48 years old and is married to a policeman. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a concrete house and pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock more bread and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Byambatsetseg

texts.en:
Byambatsetseg G., age 30, lives with her husband and two children in their own traditional housing tent, called a ger, in Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. Her eldest son attends a local secondary school, while her husband works privately to install steel doors in people's houses. 

Byambatsetseg operates a grocery store. Four years ago, before starting this business, she used to operate a shoe trading business in a stall at the Narantuul, biggest and main market in the city. She has been selling a variety of grocery products in her shop since 2009, and has built a stable operation in a short period of time. She has found success with her growing business and she has managed to expand her grocery store and create rooms to rent to people. She is planning to use her earnings from her room rental service to expand her grocery business in the future. 

Byambatsetseg is an honest and hardworking woman, and says, "I am focusing on enlarging my shop and creating more free rooms that can be rented by other individuals, then my business will expand greatly." She is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of food products at wholesale prices, and to use in the construction of her shop extension.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of food products to resell

loans.name: Julius Kibet

texts.en:
Julius Kibet M. is 33 years old and married to Dorcas M.. He is a businessman who sells clothes on a busy street in Silibwet, a town on the outskirts of Narok. He has been running this business for the past two years.

He learned about KADET LTD from a friend who is already registered as a client. This will be his first loan. He is planning to increase his inventory by buying more clothes. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to rent a permanent shop where he can sell his clothes. He plans to open another shop and create employment for other people. 

His future dream is that he will be able to build his own house and be running the shop there. Julius believes he is hardworking and he only needs the resources to attain his goals

loans.use: To buy more stock of clothes to add to his inventory

loans.name: Morine

texts.en: Morine J. is currently in the business of selling groundnut phase, beans and bread and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of beans to to sell.  Morine is 30 years old and is married to a man who works as a driver. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: Stock more bags of beans to to sell

loans.name: Sengemaa

texts.en:
Sengemaa D. is 48 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Arhangai province of Mongolia. The family all lives together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her youngest son attends high school. Her two children raise their livestock in the countryside. 

Sengemaa operates a mobile dairy trading business, in which the family prepares dairy products to sell in the local market. She started this business in 2008, and has built a stable operation. Today, her working capital has reached 500,000 MNT. In the years of running her business, Sengemaa has gained a reputation among her customers as a reliable supplier of quality dairy products. She purchases dairy products from wholesale traders and sells back at the local markets. With her earnings, she plans to prepare a new home for her son who will live on his own soon. Sengemaa needs more funds to purchase a large amount of dairy products in order to sell for the upcoming winter. Sengemaa is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan to purchase more dairy supplies in order to increase her sales.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy supplies for resale

loans.name: Wilson Ngugi

texts.en:
Wilson Ngugi M. is 34 years old and married to Njoki Priscillah. He is a businessman who has a music store on a busy street of Kitale,  Kenya. He has been running this business for the past five years.

He learned about KADET LTD from a friend who is already registered as a client. This will be his first loan. He is planning to increase his inventory by buying more CDs and tapes. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to rent a permanent shop where he can sell his CDs, and also hopes to open another music store and create employment for other people. 

His future dream is that he will be able to build his own house and be running the shop. Wilson believes he is hardworking and he only needs the resources to attain his goals

loans.use: To buy more CDs and tapes

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica P. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, onions and cooking oil and is requesting a loan to stock more Jerrycans of cooking oil to sell. Monica is 31 years old and is married to a man who is an NGO staff member. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: Stock more jerrycans of cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Hadbaatar

texts.en:
Hadbaatar J. is 45 years old and lives with his wife and adult daughter in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent, in Huvsgul province of Mongolia. His wife stays at home due to poor health and receives a pension of disability. 

Hadbaatar operates a public transport service between the local towns. He started this business in 2000, after purchasing a new microbus. Today, he works for the Nuhurlul Zam Friendship as a driver to offer public transportation two or three times per month. After many years of owning this business, he has been supporting his family as well as to pay his son's tuition fees with his business profits. 

Hadbaatar works very hard and is a quick and self-asserting man. For the future, he hopes to upgrade his car by buying new one. He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to improve his car.

loans.use: To improve his car

loans.name: Gulnoza

texts.ru: Рахимова Гулноза проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 20 лет. Не замужем. Образование среднее. Работает на рынке. Арендует торговую точку, где продает детские костюмчики. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 3 года. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en: Gulnoza R. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda.  She is 20 years old, single.  She has a secodary education and works at a market.  Gulnoza leases a retail outlet, where she sells children's clothing.  She has been involved in this business for 3 years.  She is requesting this loan in order to expand the merchandise assortment.

loans.use: Expanding assortment

loans.name: Ayush

texts.en:
Ayush L. is 46 years old and lives with his wife in Arhangai province of Mongolia. The family all lives together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. 

Ayush operates a mobile dairy trading business, selling dairy products his wife prepares to local markets. He started this business in 1996, with working capital of 50,000 MNT, which has since reached 1,900,000 MNT. In the years of running his business, Ayush has gained a reputation among his customers of being a reliable supplier of quality dairy products. He has used his earnings to provide for his son's needs. With help of his earnings, his son completed his university and started to live on his own. 

For the future, Ayush says, "I want to purchase a good quality of dairy products from herders and sell those products to local individuals." He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more dairy supplies in order to increase his sales.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy supplies to increase his sales

loans.name: Joyce Nduki

texts.en:
Joyce M., age 47, is married to Peter Muasya and together they have two children, a son aged 13 years and a daughter aged 9 years. She lives at Tala and hawks clothes from Tala market to Kagundo town and from house to house.

Joyce has been running this clothes business for four years and her monthly profit is Kshs 5,000. She uses her little profit to help her husband educate and feed their children. She was introduced to KADET LTD by the loan officer in charge of the Tala office.

Joyce is good at selecting the clothes she is selling to her customer and this has made her customers very proud of the clothes she sells.

After getting this loan, Joyce intends to increase her stock of clothes she is hawking to make more profit.

If the loan boosts the business, Joyce plans that the extra generated income will enable her to rent a house in Tala market where she can do her business instead of moving around.

Joyce is very hardworking and has big dreams for the future.

loans.use: To increase her stock of clothes for hawking

loans.name: Munh-Amgalan

texts.en: Munh-Amgalan G. is 32 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Arhangai province, Mongolia. They all live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent home.  He started his own business in 2002 operating a clothing retail trading business and has gained business experience. Today, Munh-Amgalan operates a cosmetic trading business in his town. His business has grown steadily over the years due to his loyal customers. In the beginning, he started his business with working capital of 500,000 MNT and has since reached a level of exceeding 2,500,000 MNT. In addition, he drives a taxi to supplement his earnings. In the future, Munh-Amgalan hopes to grow his business further and have his own trade center. He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase more inventory for his cosmetics trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Narantsetseg

texts.en: Narantsetseg T. is 56 years old and lives with her husband in the Han-Uul district of Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia. The family lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Narantsetseg operates a grocery trading business with the help of her husband. She began her business in 1990, selling a variety of foodstuffs in a stall. After years of hard work and diligence, she has managed to expand her business and open her own grocery store. In the future, she hopes to increase her product line for her grocery shop. Narantsetseg is a modest and hardworking woman. She is requesting an 800,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a large amount of groceries for her business.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of groceries

loans.name: Bulgantamir

texts.en: Bulgantamir S. is 35 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in Arhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His sons, ages 12 and 8, are secondary school students. Bulgantamir and his wife operate a cafe and a taxi service in their town. Bulgantamir started driving a taxi in 2002 and built a stable and successful business that has allowed him to begin operating a cafe in a rented space at the local market. His wife is responsible for managing the cafe while Bulgantamir drives a taxi. They have been successful in both ventures and have a strong customer base throughout their community. Bulgantamir wants to provide fast and reliable service for his customers. He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase necessary materials for the cafe and parts for his car.

loans.use: To purchase necessary materials for a cafe

loans.name: Shijirbaatar

texts.en: Shijirbaatar B. is 24 years old and lives with his wife and two young daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife is a student who stays home and takes care of their children. Shijirbaatar operates a business providing Internet service in the ger district. He began his business in 2006 and since then he has gained a great deal of business experience and a good reputation among his customers. Shijirbaatar’s Internet center has 20 personal computers. He would like to expand his workplace in the future and is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan for workplace construction.

loans.use: To use for workplace construction

loans.name: Yadamsuren

texts.en: Yadamsuren B. is 26 years old and lives with his wife in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in the Hovd province of Mongolia. Yadamsuren’s wife operates a sewing business in their home with help of her mother while Yadamsuren operates a taxi service in his town. He stared his business in 2006 and has gained a great deal of experience. In addition, Yadamsuren works as a bus conductor to supplement his earnings. Yadamsuren is a very hardworking man who is requesting a 1,800,000 MNT loan to leverage the profit from the sale of current car to enable him to buy a new car and improve his transportation business.

loans.use: To purchase a new car

loans.name: Let God Be Group

texts.en:
Lawrence M., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Let God Be.  He is 35 years old, single, and has two children who are between the ages of 3 and 8 years old. He is a college student. 

For ten years, he has been operating a foreign exchange bureau in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 8,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 36,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to add more money to his business.  He describes himself as a friendly man whose goal is to own a drug store.

loans.use: To add more money to his foreign exchange business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cartons of fish, meat, cooking oil, rice, beans, salt, seasoning, etc

loans.name: Yondonpuntsag

texts.en: Yondonpuntsag T. is 34 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent in his father's yard. His two children both attend a local secondary school. During the summer time, they live in the countryside herding their livestock and during winter, they move to the central city of the province. Yondonpuntsag operates a milk trading business in his town with the help of his wife. They have eight cows at his home that produce the milk he sells. On average, one of his cows can produce about four liters of milk per day. Yondonpuntsag started his milk trading business in 2007 and has had success in growing his business. He has been grazing cattle for almost his entire life and has gained much experience as a herder. He signed a contract with organizations and individuals to supply milk. In the future, he wants to prepare a stockyard and fodder for his cows. Since operating the business, he was able to improve his family's standard of living greatly. He is a real nomadic, simple-minded man.  He is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase hay to feed his cows and prepare for winter.

loans.use: To purchase hay to feed his cows

loans.name: Kanyinya Bee Keepers, Kyenjojo Group

texts.en:
Hard working and determined Z. Pafura of Kanyinya Bee keepers, Kyenjojo, aged 46, has been operating a livestock business that deals in goat rearing in Kanyinya, Kyenjojo. The married father of 8 children engages in the purchase of goats which he grazes, fattens and sells at a later stage for a better price as well as selling cows that are bought by butchers in the area.

This activity has seen him fetch 168,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis, which has helped him in taking up family responsibilities like paying the children’s fees. He is very much into stocking more livestock on the farm, thus he needs this loan to help him achieve his goal as it will help him earn more sales revenue in the near future, thus improving the family income.

loans.use: purchase of goats for the farm for fattening and resale

loans.name: Plumkor Community Group

texts.en:
Ndorbor K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Plumkor Community.  He is 45 years old, married, and has four children who are between the ages of 3 and 25 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial constraints. 

For 10 years, he has been selling timbers (planks) in Sinkor, Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 20,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 64,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more timbers (planks).

He describes himself as a God-fearing man whose goals are to improve his business and continue to the education of his children.

loans.use: To buy more timbers (planks)

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To add more money to his business

loans.name: Donathile

texts.en:
Donathile is 38 years old and married with seven children. Donathile's husband does not have a job. That's why she has to work hard in order to get everything her family needs. Before starting her business, she was not able to get whatever she needed. Now that she is in the business, she is able. This is her 12th year successful in her business and the hours of her business are from 8 in the morning to 4 in the evening every day. In this business, Donathile employs two people from her community.

Donathile is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of purchasing more bales of clothes, which will allow her to earn more profits with large quantities of clothes to be sold.

loans.use: To purchase bales of clothes

loans.name: Dorothee

texts.en:
Dorothee is 34 years old. She is married with two children who are 4 and 7 years old.  Dorothee is a self-employed businesswoman who is known for selling a variety of handcrafts items, as the picture itself indicates.  Dorothee has been in this business for about 10 years and the business hours are from early in the morning until late in the evening.

Although Dorothee has been in this business for about 10 years, her capital is still too low to expand meaningfully.  To end this, she will purchase a variety of handcrafts items for sale. These additional items will play a big part in increasing her revenue and continuing to take care of her family.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of handcrafts items.

loans.name: C4588 Abiyemeje Group

texts.en:
Theddy is 55 years old. Theddy is the leader of a group called "abiyemeje."  This group is known for selling natural medicines and they have been in this business for a long time.  The business hours are from early in the morning until late in the evening.

Theddy and her team need to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a.  With this loan, this team will expand the business through purchasing natural medicines.  With these additional natural medicines, this team will earn more profits, which in turn will allow them to keep reinvesting for better financial stability in their business.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of natural medicines

loans.name: Ssazi Twekulakulanye Women's Association-Mpigi Group

texts.en: N. Zeridda, 59, has been an agricultural product and produce seller for over 20 years in Mpigi. She mostly sells cassava, bananas and maize. She has also been selling eggs, in addition to her modest pig husbandry enterprise. A business that she says began with the influence of her mom now generates 200,000 shillings per week. Prior to this she was selling alcohol. With this loan, she says she wants to purchase more bags of cassava and maize for resale. Zeridda belongs to Ssazi Twekulakulanye Women's Association-Mpigi.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of cassava and maize

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To add more money to his business

loans.name: Abdoulaye

texts.fr:
Monsieur Abdoulaye Mété est un homme marié de 42 ans, monogame avec deux  enfants et résidant  au quartier Est, qui est un des quartiers de la ville  de Kolondièba, dans la  troisième région (Sikasso)  République Mali.  
Monsieur Mété a abandonné l’école dès le second cycle de l’enseignement fondamental (Système éducatif Malien). Pour s’insérer dans la vie économique, il fît le gardien à Save the Children pendant treize ans. Après son licenciement pour motif économique par Save, Monsieur Mété se lance dans le commerce en ouvrant une boutique de vente d’articles divers au marché de Kolondièba. 
Pour augmenter son capital il adhère au programme crédit de  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  il est à son premier  prêt. 
Avec ce prêt il compte acheter, 500 kg de sucre, un carton de cigarettes, deux cartons de thé, quelques sacs de céréales etc.   
Il compte faire prospérer son commerce en faisant varier ses articles pour réaliser un chiffre d’affaire plus élevé dans les moments à venir. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice de 45.000 FCFA par mois. Le bénéfice   sera investi dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Abdoulaye Mété is a 42-year-old married man who is monogamous.  He has two children and resides in East District, one of the districts of the city of Kolondièba, in the 3rd region (Sikasso), the Republic of Mali.  He dropped out of school in the second cycle of primary school (educational system of Mali).  To earn a living, he was a security guard at Save the Children for thirteen years.  After he was laid off there for economic reasons, he got started in commerce by opening a shop selling various goods at the Kolondièba market.

To increase his capital, Mr. Mété joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso loan program and is now on his first loan.  With this loan, he plans to buy 500 kg of sugar, a box of cigarette, two boxes of tea, some sacks of grain, etc.  He plans on his business prospering by varying his goods and making more sales in the days ahead. He expects to make a profit of 45,000 francs CFA per month.  The profits will be invested in his enterprise.

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more pork and pig's feet

loans.name: Evariste

texts.en:
Evariste is 46 years old and married with eight children.  Evariste owns a small general store which sells a variety of products including food and household products. His business is profitable and is well known in his area. This is his third successful year in business. He employs two people from his community and is open from 7am until 10 every day, except Saturdays.

Evariste has requested a loan to purchase additional products for his store, such as salt, cooking oil, rice, and so on. With this loan, Evariste hopes to be able to earn more profit.

loans.use: To purchase additional products

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, sugar and flour

loans.name: Arouna

texts.fr:
Monsieur Arouna S. est un homme marié de 38 ans qui vit dans une famille polygame avec ses 3 enfants et leurs mères au  Quartier- Ouest dans la ville de  Kolondièba, chef lieu de la  Préfecture du même nom, dans la  troisième région (Sikasso) de la République Mali  
Pour augmenter son capital il adhère au programme crédit de  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son deuxième  prêt. Le premier fut correctement remboursé.  
Monsieur S. a dix ans d’expérience dans cette activité d’achat et de vente d’animaux.
Il achète les bœufs dans la Préfecture de Kolondièba et les revend  en Côte Ivoire, surtout pendant les fêtes de Ramadan et  de Tabaski, à Bougouni et Nièna au Mali pendant le reste de la saison. 
La vente ce fait  généralement au comptant  et quelques fois à crédit.   
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice de 100.000 FCFA par mois. Le bénéfice  sera investi dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Arouna S. is a 38-year-old married man who lives in a polygamous family. He lives with his three children and their mothers in the Quartier-Ouest of the town of Kolondièba, the administrative center of the prefecture of the same name, in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali.

To increase his working capital he subscribes to the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso with whom it is his second loan. The first one was fully reimbursed.

Mr. S. has 10 years of experience in the business of buying and selling livestock. He buys the bulls in the Prefecture of Kolondièba and resells them in Ivory Coast especially during the Ramadan and Tabaski (Eid al-Adha) holidays. The rest of the season he sells in Bougouni and in Nièna in Mali. The sale is usually made in cash and sometimes on credit. 

He hopes to make a monthly profit of 100, 000 Francs CFA. The profit will be reinvested in the business.

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Korotimi

texts.fr:
Madame Korotimi Koné est une femme mariée de 43 ans qui vit  dans une famille nucléaire avec son mari et ses cinq enfants  dans le quartier Est  de Kolondièba dans la  troisième région (Sikasso) de la République du Mali. 
Pour augmenter son capital, elle décide d’adhérer au prêt  individuel de stockage et commercialisation de céréales de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son troisième cycle. 
Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Kolondièba les jours de foire auprès des producteurs et grossistes et dans les villages environnants.
Avec ce prêt, il compte acheter, 1000  kilogrammes de riz, 1000  kilogrammes de mil qu’il stockera pour revendre en une période où le cours  sera plus élevé.
 Elle compte   réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les frais scolaires, de santé des enfants et payer des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
Mrs. Korotimi Koné is a 43-year-old married woman who lives in a nuclear family with her husband and five children in the eastern district of Kolondièba in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali. 

In order to increase her working capital, she decided to join the individual loan program for stocking and selling cereals of Soro Yiriwaso, with whom she is on her third loan cycle.

She gets her supplies at the Kolondièba market from farmers and wholesale traders on fair days and in surrounding villages.

With this loan, she intends to purchase 1,000 kilograms of rice and 1,000 kilograms of millet that she will stock to resell at a time when the price will be higher. 

She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 15,000 CFA francs that will be used to pay for the children's schooling costs and medical care and to buy small ruminants.

loans.use: To purchase cereals

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more T-shirts and men underclothes

loans.name: Maïmouna

texts.fr:
Madame Maïmouna D. est une femme mariée de 48ans qui vit  dans une famille traditionnelle élargie avec ses sept enfants, ses coépouses ainsi que leur  mari  dans le quartier Est  de Kolondièba dans la  troisième région (Sikasso) de la République du Mali. 
Pour augmenter son capital elle décide d’aller au prêt  individuel de stockage et commercialisation de céréales de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son quatrième cycle. 
Elle s’approvisionne au marché de  Kolondièba les jours de foire et dans les villages environnants.
Avec ce prêt, il compte avoir 1000  kilogrammes de riz, 1000  kilogrammes de maïs qu’il stockera pour revendre en une période où le cours  sera élevé.
 Elle compte   réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  50.000 FCFA  qui sera investi dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maïmouna D. is a 48-year-old married woman who lives in an extended traditional family with her seven children, her co-wives and their husbands in the East Kolondièba district of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

She is seeking an individual loan for grain storage and marketing from the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, with whom she is on her fourth loan cycle. This will help increase her working capital. 

She gets her stocks at the Kolondièba market on fair days, and in surrounding villages.

With this loan, she will purchase 1,000 kg of rice and 1,000 kg of maize, to be stored until market prices are high enough.

She expects to make an average monthly profit of 50,000 FCFA to be invested in the business.

loans.use: To purchase grain

loans.name: Seydou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Seydou Koné  est un homme marié de 38 ans, polygame et  père de quatre enfants vivant à Kèlèkèlè l’un des villages de la Sous-préfecture de Tousséguéla dans la grande famille traditionnelle, Préfecture de Kolondièba  dans la troisième région (Sikasso) de la République du  Mali. 
Pour mieux alléger sa pauvreté, Monsieur Koné adhéra au programme  crédit de  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  il est à son quatre cycle.
Avec ce prêt, il compte avoir 400  kilogrammes de grains d’arachide, 1000  kilogrammes de mil et 2000 kilogrammes de maïs qu’il stockera pour revendre en une période où le cours sera plus élevé.
 Il s’approvisionne au marché de Kolondièba les jours de foire et revend à Bamako à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de revendeurs. 
Il espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  30. 000 FCFA  
En perspective il compte ouvrir un grand magasin à Kolondièba chef lieu de la préfecture enfin de satisfaire sa clientèle qui devient de plus nombreuse.
Le bénéfice servira à prendra en charge les frais scolaires,  de santé, de nourriture et le reste sera  investi dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Seydou Koné is a 38-year-old married man who is polygamous and the father of four children.  He lives in a large traditional family in Kèlèkèlè, a village in Tousséguéla sub-prefecture, Kolondièba prefecture, in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali.

To better reduce his poverty, Mr. Koné joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso loan program and is now on his fourth loan cycle.  With the new loan, he intends to obtain 400 kg of peanut seeds, 1,000 kg of millet, and 2,000 kg of corn that he will stock up for resale when prices are higher.  He gets his supplies from the Kolondièba market on the days when the fair is held.  He sells in Bamako to a customer base composed essentially of retailers. He hopes to make an average monthly profit of 30,000 francs CFA.  

Looking forward, he hopes to open a large store in Kolondièba, the prefecture seat, in order to satisfy his customers, who are becoming more numerous.  The profits will be used to cover schooling costs, health care, and food.  The rest of it will be invested in his business.

loans.use: Buying grains

loans.name: Artak

texts.en:
Artak A. is 30 years old. He is married and has two children. Since March, 2010, Artak has operated his own woodworking workshop in Ijevan city. He takes orders from clients and sells his products by himself as well. He produces half-finished parquets and other semi-finished products. Thanks to his business income, Artak maintains his young family and bought a car for his business.

Artak asks for a 500,000 Armenian drams loan to buy calipers for his carpentry business.

loans.use: To buy calipers for his carpentry business

loans.name: Chiaka

texts.fr:
Monsieur Chiaka Koné  est un homme marié de 28 ans polygame et père de deux  enfants vivant à Woma, un des villages de la Sous-préfecture de Fakola, dans une grande famille traditionnelle, Préfecture de Kolondièba  dans la troisième région (Sikasso) de la République du  Mali. 
Pour mieux alléger sa pauvreté, Monsieur Koné adhéra au programme de prêt individuel de stockage et commercialisation de céréales de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  il est à son quatre cycle.
Avec ce prêt, il compte avoir 400  kilogrammes de grains d’arachide, 1000  kilogrammes de mil et 200 kilogrammes de maïs qu’il stockera pour revendre à la période de cours élevé.
 Il s’approvisionne dans  les  villages environnants et espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  50. 000 FCFA. Le bénéfice prendra en charge les frais scolaire, de santé,  de nourriture et le reste sera  investi dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Chiaka Koné  is a married man of 28, polygamist and the father of two childrren,  living in a big traditional family.in Woma, one of the villages in the Sous-prefecture of Fakola, Prefecture of Kolondièba,  in the third administrative region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali. 
 
In order to relieve his poverty, Mr. Koné is a member of an individual loan program for stocking and sales of cereals through Soro Yiriwaso, with whom he is on his fourth loan. 

With this loan, he counts on having 400 kg of hulled peanuts, 1000 kg. of millet, and 200 kg of maize which he will stockpile in order to sell the cereals when the price is higher. 

He buys his cereals in the surrounding villages and hopes to make a monthly average profit of 50,000 F CFA. The profit will allow him to cover school fees, health expenditures, and pay for food. Any remainder will be invested back into his business.

loans.use: buying cereals for resale

loans.name: Delphine

texts.en: Delphine was born in 1977. She is married with two children: the first one is 13 and the last one is 6 years old. Delphine is a business woman; her husband does not make any income for the family. Delphine owns a store which sells various products such as sacs of rice, sugar, maize flour, cooking oil and so on. She is well known for her business which is well organized. Delphine has four years of experience in this business. She is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase additional products for her store. Delphine expects to earn more profit after expanding her business and she will be able to satisfy her customers.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for sale

loans.name: Karim

texts.fr:
Monsieur Karim D. est un homme marié de 22 ans monogame avec un  enfant, il réside au quartier- Koko de Fakola, une sous–préfecture de Kolondièba dans la  troisième région (Sikasso) de la République Mali. 
Monsieur D. a appris cette activité d’achat et de vente d’articles divers auprès de son grand frère qui est commerçant lui aussi au marché de Fakola. Karim D. a sept ans d’expérience dans l’activité  et est très sollicité.
Afin d’augmenter son capital il adhère au programme  crédit de  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  il est à son deuxième cycle. 
Avec ce prêt il compte acheter, 1000 kg de sucre, vingt cartons de cigarettes, dix cartons de thé, des cartons de  savons, des paquets de bonbons, etc. 
Il s’approvisionne auprès des grossistes et effectue sa vente à une clientèle diverse et variée, en détail au comptant et souvent à crédit.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice de 75.000FCFA par mois. Le bénéfice   sera investi dans la construction une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mr. Karim D. is a married man of 22, monogamous and the father of one child. He lives in the Koko neighborhood of Fakola, a sous-prefecture of Kolondièba in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali. 
 
Mr. D. apprenticed in the buying and selling of general merchandise with his older brother who is also a businessman in the open-air market of Fakola. Karim D. has seven years' experience in the business and is much sought after. 

In order to grow his working capital, he joined the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso with whom he is on his second loan. With this loan he is counting on buying 1000 kg of sugar, 20 cartons of cigarettes, 10 cases of tea, cases of soap, packets of candy, etc.
 
He buys his wares from wholesalers and sells to a diverse clientele, retail, for cash and often on credit. He expects to make a profit of 75,000 F CFA a month. The profit will be invested in the construction of a residential house.

loans.use: purchase of various items for resale

loans.name: Armen

texts.en:
Armen A. is 29 years old. He is married and lives in Tsovaghugh village in the Sevan area with his wife and his 1-year-old baby.

Armen is a mechanical engineer, but he manages his own business: spare parts for cars. In the near future, Armen will become a father for the second time, so he intends to increase his family’s income thanks to his business development. 

To achieve his goal, Armen asks for a 800,000 Armenian drams loan, which will allow him to adapt and repair part of his shop for a household goods trading organization and to buy merchandise for it.

loans.use: To adapt and repair part of his shop for a household goods trading organization and to buy merchandise for it

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.fr:
Monsieur Mohamed Koné est un homme marié de 49 ans polygame qui est père de douze enfants. Il  vit avec ses deux épouses à Socourani, l’un des villages de la sous-préfecture de Fakola  dans une  famille traditionnelle élargie, Préfecture de Kolondièba  dans la troisième région (Sikasso) de la République du  Mali. 
 Monsieur Koné adhéra au programme crédit du prêt individuel de stockage et commercialisation de céréales de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  il est à son sixième cycle. Tous les prêts précédents ont été remboursés et à temps.
Avec ce prêt, il compte avoir acheter,  20 tonnes  de maïs pour les revendre à Bamako, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de revendeurs et de quelques consommateurs.  Il s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants et espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  150. 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les frais scolaire, de santé, de nourriture et ambitionne construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mr. Mohamed Koné is 49 years old, polygamous and the father of 12. He lives with his two wives in a traditional extended family in Socourani, a village in the subprefecture of Fakola, prefecture of Kolondièba, the third administrative region (Sikasso) of Mali.

Mr. Koné has joined the individual loan program of Soro Yirwaso because of his business of storing and selling cereals, and is now on his sixth loan. All prior loans have been repaid on time.

With this loan he plans to purchase 20 tons [about 44000 lbs] of corn in order to resell them to Bamako, to a customer base composed mainly of resellers as well as some consumers. He stocks up in the nearby villages and hopes to achieve an average monthly revenue of 150,000 West African francs, which will be used to for school fees, healthcare and food expenses. Hi s goal is to build a house to live in.

loans.use: Purchasing cereals

loans.name: Siatta

texts.fr:
Madame Siatta Koné est une femme mariée de 30 ans qui vit  dans  une famille traditionnelle avec ses douze enfants, ses co-épouses et leur  mari  dans le village Socourani dans la Sous-préfecture de Fakola, préfecture de Kolondièba dans la  troisième région (Sikasso) de la République du Mali. 
Pour augmenter son capital elle décide d’aller au  prêt  individuel de stockage et commercialisation de céréales de Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est à son troisième  cycle, après avoir correctement remboursé les deux prêts précédents. 
Elle s’approvisionne à Socourani et dans les villages environnants.
Avec ce prêt, il compte acheter, 10.000  kilogrammes de riz, 1000  kilogrammes de maïs.
 Elle compte   réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  150.000 FCFA qui  sera investi dans l’achat de petits animaux.
texts.en:
Mrs. Siatta Koné is a 30-year-old married woman. She lives in a traditional family with her twelve children, her co-spouses, and their husband in the village of Socourani in the sub-prefecture of Kolondièba in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali.

To increase her capital she decided to seek an individual loan from Soro Yiriwaso to stock and sell cereals. She is on her third loan cycle, having fully repaid the two preceding loans.

She gets her supplies in Socourani and surrounding villages. With this loan, she plans to buy 10,000 kilograms of rice and 1000 kilograms of corn.

She plans to make an average monthly profit of 150,000 FCFA, which will be used to purchase small animals.

loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Soumaïla

texts.fr:
Monsieur Soumaïla D.  est un homme marié de 31ans polygame et père d’un  enfant, vivant Socourani,  un des villages de la Sous-préfecture de Fakola dans la grande famille traditionnelle, Préfecture de Kolondièba  dans la troisième région (Sikasso) de la République du  Mali. 
Pour mieux alléger sa pauvreté, Monsieur D.  adhéra au programme de prêt individuel de stockage et commercialisation de céréales de Soro Yiriwaso. Il  est à son premier prêt.
Avec ce prêt, il compte acheter,  400  kilogrammes de grains fonio, 1000  kilogrammes de maïs et 200 kilogrammes de mil qu’il stockera pour revendre en un moment où le prix sera plus intéressant. Il s’approvisionne dans  les  villages environnants et envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  100. 000 FCFA.
texts.en:
Mr. Soumaïla D. is a 31-year-old polygamous, married man and father of one who lives in a large traditional family in Socourani, one of the subprefecture villages of Fakola, prefecture of Kolondièba, in the third region (Sikasso) in the Republic of Mali. 

To better reduce his poverty, Mr. D. joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso loan program. This is his first loan. With this loan, he plans to buy 400 kilograms of fonio grains, 1000 kilograms of corn, and 200 kilograms of millet, which he will stock up for resale when prices are higher. He gets his supplies from neighboring villages and foresees making a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA.

loans.use: to buy grains

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For over 10 years, she has operated her rental houses and also does cooking of half cakes for resale. She faces a challenge of the hike in food prices. Khadija hopes to build other rental houses in the future.

She decided to join Yehu to get education on proper usage of loans. With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour and materials to renovate her house.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour and materials to renovate her house

loans.name: Laubene

texts.en:
Laubene was born in 1980. He is married with two children: the first one is 9 years old and the last one is 7 years old. Laubene is a businessman and his wife helps in the store. He has two years of experience in this business. The hours of his daily activities are from 6 in the morning to 6 in the evening every day.

Laubene is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase additional products for his store. With this loan, Laubene will be able to sell a large quantities of products, which is the best way of earning more profits to be used for his family and for his business as well.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for sale

loans.name: Celline Awino

texts.en:
Celline Awino O., 34 and married to Maurice, who works as a support staff member in a Nairobi hospital, is the mother of three children ranging in age from seven to two years. Celine has had a fish-selling business for one year and earns a good income. The operation is located in the Kangemi business shopping centre, and her main customers are people who are conducting business in the same place and passersby.

Celline, introduced to KADET LTD by a friend, has no history with any other MFI, and this will be her first loan with KADET. She intends to add to her stock of small local fish known as omena and buy a big basket for carrying the fish to the marketplace where she sells.

She desires to grow her business and be the leading supplier of fish in Kangemi centre and also distribute fish to other business people. She is very hardworking lady with a good and hospitable heart who serves people so well.

loans.use: To add stock worth Kshs.7,000 and buy a basket worth Kshs.3,000

loans.name: Youssouf

texts.fr:
Monsieur Youssouf  Koné  est un homme marié de 32ans polygame et père de trois enfants qui  vit, à Soromana, un des villages de la Sous-préfecture de Fakola dans la  famille nucléaire, Préfecture de Kolondièba  dans la troisième région (Sikasso) de la République du  Mali. 
Pour mieux alléger sa pauvreté, Monsieur Youssouf Koné adhéra au programme  crédit Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son deuxième cycle. Le premier prêt fut remboursé sans aucune difficulté.
Avec ce prêt, il compte acheter,  400  kilogrammes de maïs, 1000  kilogrammes de petit mil et 2000 kilogrammes de riz qu’il stockera pour revendre à la période de cours élevé.
 Il s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants  et envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  30.000F CFA 
Le bénéfice prendra en charge les frais scolaire, de santé,  de nourriture et le reste sera  investi dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Youssouf  Koné  is a 32-year-old polygamous married man, and the father of three children. He lives within a nuclear family in Soromana, one of the villages in the sub-prefecture of Fakola, part of the Kolondieba prefecture in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali.

To alleviate poverty, Mr. Youssouf Koné joined the Soro Yiriwaso credit loan program where he is beginning his second loan cycle. The first loan was reimbursed without any difficulties.

With this loan he intends to buy: 400 kilos of corn, 1000 kilos of millet and 2000 kilos of rice he will stockpile for resale at a period of high retail prices. He gets his supplies from neighbouring villages and hopes to attain average monthly earnings of 30,000 FCFA.

Profits will be used to cover schooling, healthcare, and food costs, and the remainder will be reinvested in the business.

loans.use: Buy grain cereals

loans.name: Yousouf

texts.fr:
Monsieur Youssouf Koné  est un homme marié de 35 ans et père de 5 enfants, qui vit dans une famille polygame dans le village de Soromana,  sous-préfecture de Fakola dans la préfecture de Kolondièba dans la  troisième région (Sikasso) de la République Mali.
Youssouf n’ayant pas fréquenté l’école s’est très vite intéressé aux activités génératrices de revenus. Il finit par opter pour l’achat vente de bétails, car les autres activités  ne lui ont pas réussies.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, il décide d’adhérer au programme  crédit de l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son premier prêt. 
Monsieur Koné a six ans d’expérience dans cette activité. Il est très sollicité et apprécié à Fakola,  Kolondièba et en Côte d’Ivoire.
Il achète les bœufs dans la commune de Fakola et environnants et effectue sa vente en  république de Côte Ivoire, à  Nièna et Koumantou au Mali dans les marchés à bétails. La vente se fait au comptant souvent à crédit, à une clientèle constituée de bouchers, d’éleveurs et bien d’autres catégories sociales.   
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice de 200.000FCFA par mois. Le bénéfice  sera investi dans les frais scolaire, santé, condiments  et la nourriture.
texts.en:
Mr. Youssouf Kiné is a 35-year-old married man, father of five children, who lives in a polygamous family in the village of Soromana, one of the villages in the sub-prefecture of Fakola, part of the Kolondieba prefecture in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali.

As Youssouf did not attend school he took an early interest in revenue-generating activities. He finally opted to buy and sell cattle, as his other activities were not successful.

While searching for additional financial resources, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI’s credit loan program, where he is beginning his first loan cycle.

Mr. Koné has six years’ experience in this line of business. He is well appreciated and sought after in Fakola, Kolondieba, and in Ivory Coast. He buys cattle in Fakola and the surrounding area and sells them in Ivory Coast, and at cattle markets in Niema and Koumantou in Mali.

Sales are made in cash and often on credit, to a customer base of butchers, ranchers and from many other social categories. He hopes to attain monthly earnings of 200,000 FCFA. The profits will be invested in schooling fees, healthcare, food condiments and food.

loans.use: Buy cattle

loans.name: Rec Kossoh Towm Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone, is pleased to present to you teachers of the REC Kossoh Town School, in Waterloo, a small town, where “Shine on Sierra Leone” has partnered with SMT to start a branch. This school was founded in 1964. The school is staffed with eleven teachers and has 287 pupils.   

These hard-working and dedicated teachers have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to seek a loan of SLL 7,500,000. With the help of this loan, these teachers can embark on some meaningful project that their mere salaries alone can not do. Some of them will use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, others to buy house-building materials; some will buy a piece of land or pay school fees for their children, while others will invest the loan in business. 

Nat J. is the leader of this group of teachers. Born in Kossoh Town, near Waterloo, Nat is married to a clerk and the couple has seven children who are attending secondary school. Nat has served in the teaching profession for thirty-eight years now.  Nat will use part of his share of this loan to renovate his house and use the rest to buy seeds to plant in his farm.

loans.use: renovate his house and  buy seeds to plant

loans.name: Lesya

texts.en:
Lesya is married with two sons. She is an entrepreneur from the town of Khoost, Western Ukraine. Lesya runs a small business selling bicycles that are in high demand in her small town where very few people can afford to buy and own a car. Along with bicycles, she also sells different parts and accessories for them. Lesya works really hard to keep her business sustainable and running smoothly. Lesya has been operating her business for 3 years. Currently, she earns about 4,300 UAH a month in net profit.

Lesya hopes to develop her business further. She is thinking about purchasing additional merchandise to facilitate her sales and business activity. She is requesting a loan of 8,000 UAH to help her offer a larger variety of this type of merchandise.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise for her bike shop

loans.name: Zoumana

texts.fr:
Monsieur Zoumana Konaté est âgé de 40 ans,  marié et père de quatre enfants. Il réside dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie au quartier- Koko de Fakola, une sous–préfecture de la préfecture de Kolondièba,  troisième région (Sikasso) de la République Mali. 
Pour des raisons sociales, Zoumana Konaté abandonne prématurément les études pour s’intéresser aux activités génératrices de revenus auprès des son grand qui faisait l’achat et la vente de poissons. Après des années d’apprentissage, Zoumana décide d‘évoluer en solo en menant la même activité que son grand père et cela  depuis maintenant  dix  ans. 
Il est très sollicité et apprécié par les ménagères et revendeurs des villages voisins.
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse, il adhère au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son deuxième cycle de prêt après avoir correctement remboursé le premier. 
Avec ce prêt il compte acheter, 1000 kg de poissons fumés auprès des producteurs pêcheurs au marché de Kolondièba, Bamako et quelques fois dans les campements de pêcheurs.
Il  espère réaliser un bénéfice de 125.000F CFA par mois. Le bénéfice sera investi frais de santé et dans la construction  d’une maison d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mr. Zoumana Konate is 40 years old, married and the father of four children. He lives in a large traditional extended family in the Koko borough of the sub-prefecture of Fakola, part of the Kolondieba prefecture in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali.

For social reasons, Zoumana Konate prematurely quit school to pursue revenue-generating activities with his grandfather, whose occupation was the retail trading of fish. After years of apprenticeship, Zoumana decided to practice on his own the same activity as his grandfather, and has been in this line of business for the past ten years. He is very much in demand and is well appreciated by housewives and retailers from neighbouring villages.

Wanting to satisfy his ever-increasing customer base, he joined the Soro Yiriwaso MFI’s credit loan program. He is beginning his second loan cycle having correctly reimbursed the first.

With this loan he intends to buy 1000 kilos of smoked fish from fishermen at the Kolondieba and Bamako markets, or sometimes at fishermen campsites.

He hopes to attain monthly earnings of 125,000 FCFA. The profits will be invested in healthcare and the construction of a new home.

loans.use: Buy smoked fish

loans.name: Tabitha  Koki

texts.en:
Tabitha Koki, age 36, is married to James Mutuku who is an army officer and together they have three sons and one daughter. She lives and maintains her business in Tala.

Tabitha has been running this shop for three years and her monthly profit is 10,000 KES, which she uses to cater for the basic needs in the house and help her husband educate their children. 

Tabitha was introduced to KADET LTD by the loan officer in charge of the Tala office. After getting this loan, she intends to buy different materials to make clothes to sell so as to be able to make more profit. If the loan boosts the business, Tabitha plans that the extra generated income will be used to buy more materials that will enable her to have a variety of designs for sell and this will expand her business.

Tabitha has very satisfied customers, is very hardworking, and has big dreams for the future.

loans.use: Buy materials for making clothes

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr:
Monsieur Adama Dramé  est un homme marié de 37 ans qui vit dans une famille polygame. Il est père de six enfants et habitant  Koko, un des quartiers de Fakola, Préfecture de Kolondièba  dans la troisième région (Sikasso)  République du  Mali. 
Pour mieux alléger sa pauvreté, Monsieur Dramé adhéra au programme du prêt individuel de stockage- commercialisation de céréales de Soro Yiriwaso auquel il est à son deuxième cycle.
Avec ce prêt, il compte avoir 4000 kilogrammes de maïs, 1000  kilogrammes de petit sorgo et 2000 kilogrammes de riz qu’il stockera pour revendre en une période où le cours  sera plus élevé.
 Il s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants et espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 50.000  FCFA qui sera utilisé pour prendra en charge les frais scolaire,  de santé et  nourriture.
texts.en:
Mr. Adama Drame is a 37-year-old married man who lives in a polygamous family. He is the father of six children and lives in Koko, one of the boroughs of Fakola, part of the Kolondieba prefecture in the third region (Sikasso) of the Republic of Mali.

To alleviate poverty, Mr. Drame joined the Soro Yiriwaso individual loan program for stocking and trading grain cereals, and is beginning his second loan cycle.

With this loan he intends to buy 4000 kilos of corn, 1000 kilos of sorghum and 2000 kilos of rice that he will stockpile to be resold at a time of high selling prices.

He resupplies in neighbouring villages and hopes to attain average monthly earnings of 50,000 FCFA he will use to cover schooling, healthcare, and food costs.

loans.use: Buy grain cereals

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djekafo sont des femmes mariées  dans des familles polygames, avec en moyenne 35 ans, 4 enfants et résidant toutes dans le centre de Fakola l’une des Sous préfecture de Sikasso (3ème Région administrative du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et font toutes le commerce de céréales sauf Bakoro Koné, un des membres du groupe excelle  dans l’achat vente des articles divers. Elle achète  les paquets de cigarettes, bonbons, sucre, thés  etc.
Dans le but d’étoffer leurs fonds de commerce et de diversifier les articles à vendre, elles ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur premier   prêt solidaire. 
Bakoro Koné compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des articles divers  auprès des grossistes au marché de Fakola. Bakoro effectue sa vente à domicile, à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes qui achètent au comptant et parfois à crédit. 
A l’instar des autres membres du groupe, elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et prendre en charge les petits besoins de la famille en condiments.
texts.en:
The members of the Djekafo group are married women in polygamous families, on average 35 years old with four children, and all residing in the centre of Fakola, one of the sub-prefectures of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali).

They became acquainted as neighbours and all are retailers of grain cereals excepting Bakoro Kone, who excels in retailing various items. She retails cigarettes, candy, sugar, tea, etc.

Wanting to bolster their stock supply and diversify the items for sale, they decided to join Soro Yiriwaso where they are beginning a first group loan cycle.

Bakoro Kone wants to use her loan to buy various items from wholesalers at the Fakola market. Bakoro sells door-to-door, to mainly women customers, for cash and sometimes for credit.

As with other group members, she hopes to attain average monthly earnings of 18,000 FCFA which will serve to reimburse the loan and take care of the family’s food condiment needs.

loans.use: Buy various items

loans.name: Ma. Pinky

texts.en:
Ma. Pinky W. is from the town of Veruela. She is 38 years old. Ma. Pinky is married and has 3 school-aged children. She and her husband are both farmers. They plant and harvest rice crops to be sold to the market. They also own a rice mill. Ma. Pinky raises pigs, too. She grows them for fattening and sale.

Ma. Pinky joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Pinky has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ma. Pinky is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP that will be used to purchase farm supplies, piglets and feeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies, piglets and feeds

loans.name: Matano

texts.en:
Matano is married man with a child who attends school. He lives in his own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Matano’s greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Matano operates a business making jikos, Kenyan ceramic cook stoves, for resale. His potential customers are women who purchase jikos for cooking.
